titleproper.value:
Guide to the Bowers Family Papers
                    <num>MS 2902</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Christine George

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2014-05-28T10:22-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The Bowers family settled in upstate New York near Cooperstown in the first years of the nineteenth century and became one of its most prominent families. This collection primarily consists of correspondence to and from Bowers family members as well as documents concerning the family’s land transactions.

p.value: This collection should be cited as the Bowers Family Papers, MS 2902, The New-York Historical Society.

<emph render="italic"> Nathan Bowers</emph>, 
                <emph render="italic"> Daily Star</emph>, Aug. 31, 2005, available at http://old.thedailystar.com/news/community/obits/2005/08/ob0831.html.
                <lb/>
This collection, which spans from 1686 to 1982, is organized into seven series: Correspondence; Legal Papers; Financial Materials; Surveys; Photographs; Books; Genealogy Research; and Ephemera.

dsc.value:
Series I: Correspondence 1 1767–1982 Scope and Content Note

Series I consists of two subseries. The bulk of the materials is from the Bowers Family and were written during the nineteenth century. There are also materials from the Bowers's extended family.

 Subseries A: Bowers Family Correspondence 1767–1982, undated Scope and Content

Subseries A consists of correspondence to and from the Bowers family. The bulk of this correspondence is from the nineteenth century, but some date back to the late eighteenth century and as far forward as the late twentieth century. Most of this correspondence deals with day-to-day family matters. Because there were a number of letters to Margaretta Bowers and Martha S. Bowers, their correspondence is separated. The rest of the correspondence is placed in general correspondence and arranged chronologically.

 General Correspondence 1 1 1767–1798 General Correspondence 1 2 1801–1839 Correspondence to Margaretta M.S. Bowers 1 3 1803–1841 Correspondence to Martha S. Bowers 1 4 1839–1874 General Correspondence 1 5 1841–1894 General Correspondence 1 6 1901–1982 General Correspondence 1 7 undated Subseries B: Other Family Correspondence 1808–1938 Scope and Content

Subseries B consists of correspondence specifically to and from the Stewart and Smith families. Martha Wilson and her cousins Alexander L. Stewart and Charles S. Stewart make up the entirety of the Stewart family correspondence. The Smith family section consists mainly of correspondence from Roy Smith’s efforts to gather genealogical information about his family.

 Correspondence to Martha Wilson 1 8 1808–1850 Correspondence to Martha Wilson from A.L. Stewart 1 9 1822–1835 Correspondence from Charles S. Stewart 1 10 1854–1858 Smith Family Correspondence 1 11 1909–1938 Series II: Legal Papers 1 3 4 2 Scope and Content

This series contains two subseries with materials relating to land transactions as well as specific legal instruments for the family.

 Subseries A: Property Documents 4 2 3 1741-1901, undated Scope and Content

Subseries A contains documents pertaining to the Bowers family’s land transactions. These documents include leases, bonds for deed, releases, various state documents, as well as a variety of real property documents. All of these documents are arranged chronologically.

 Indentures 2 1 1741-1791 Indentures (Numbered) 2 2 1792 Indentures 2 3 1792 Indentures 2 4 1792 Indentures 2 5 1793-1799 Indentures 3 1 1800-1803 Indentures 3 2 1804-1810 Indentures 3 3 1812-1901, undated Bonds for Deed 4 1 1765-1818 Bonds for Deed 4 2 1819-1950 Releases 4 3 1788-1837 State Documents 4 4 1769-1885, undated Assorted Real Property Documents 4 5 1760-1884, undated Oversized Leases OS 1 1714/15–1789 Oversized Assorted Real Property Documents OS 1 1686–1817 Subseries B: Estate, Marriage, Court, and Congressional Documents 4 1 1748-1933, undated Scope and Content

Subseries B contains other legal documents for the family. These include wills, marriage licenses, assorted court documents as well as two Congressional decrees.

 Bowers Family 4 6 1872–1918 Other Family 4 7 1799–1933, undated Oversized Legal Materials OS 1 1748–1777 Series III: Financial Materials 5 6 2 5 4 7 8 1 1761–1907, undated Scope and Content

This series contains the Bowers family’s financial records. There are promissory notes as well as bills and receipts. Much of this series consists of accounting information on the properties, both in loose and bound forms. The bound volumes in this series, many of which are ledgers or rent roll books, refer to various lots the Bowers family owned.

 Promissory Notes 5 1 1761–1835 Loose Ledger Information 5 2 1812-1879, undated Bills and Receipts 5 3 1772–1848, undated Finance Notes and Ephemera 5 4 undated Untitled Ledger 1 1762–1795 Day Book 2 1840–1841 Rent Roll and Ledger of the Estate of John M. Bowers 3 1846–1850 Untitled Ledger 4 1847 Inventory Landed Property Belonging to Mrs. M.M.S. Bowers, 5 1853 Estate of Margaretta M. S. Bowers Deceased 6 1872–1879 W.A. Collins Rent Book 7 1907 Rent Roll Book 8 undated Series IV: Surveys OS 5 1675–1860, undated Scope and Content

This series consists of land surveys of the lots of land the Bowers family owned in upstate New York. The surveys are either written descriptions of the lots or drawings. Also included in the oversized section of this series is a drawing of Henry Bower Jr.’s Bowerstown.

 Descriptions and Notes 5 5 1673–1860 Descriptions and Notes 5 6 undated Diagrams and Maps 5 7 1773–1850 Diagrams and Maps 5 8 undated Oversized Diagrams and Maps OS 1 1791–1816, undated Series V: Photographs 6 1880–1950, undated Scope and Content

This series consists of photographs, both loose and bound. The loose photographs are divided into those that are annotated with either names or dates and those that are not. The photo albums contain four pictures from Matthew Brady’s National Portrait Gallery as well as a few photographs taken by E. Anthony. Matthew Brady and E. Anthony were well known photographers during the Civil War. Brady was known for the portraits he took of many famous individuals of the era. The albums also contain other recognizable individuals including Major General John Adams Dix, General E. Wool, U.S. Navy Captain G.B. Wilson, James Fenimore Cooper, Secretary of State William H. Seward, Major Robert Anderson, and Union Army General Winfield Scott Handcock.

 Annotated Photographs 6 1 1880–1950, undated Unnannotated Photographs 6 2 undated Large Photographs 6 3 undated Photo Album A 6 undated Photo Album B 6 undated Series VI: Books 9 7 13 12 10 11 1817-1926 Scope and Content

This series consists of three subseries which contain a ship log, printed books, and family bibles.

 Subseries A: Unpublished Books 9 1913–1926 Scope and Content

Subseries A contains Roy Campbell Smith’s U.S. Navy Log. Smith was a naval officer, later Governor of Guam, and Spotswood Dandridge Bowers's father-in-law.

 Roy Smith, U.S. Navy Ship Log 9 1913–1926 Subseries B: Published Books 11 7 10 1817-1922 Scope and Content

Subseries B contains several published works connected with the Bowers family.

 Cadwallader D. Colden, The Life of Robert Fulton, New York: Kirk & Mercein, 1817. 7 1817 Washington Irving, A History of the Life and Voyages of Christopher Columbus in Three Volumes, volume 1, New York: G. & C. Carvill, 1828. 7 1828 Washington Irving, A History of the Life and Voyages of Christopher Columbus in Three Volumes, volume 2, New York: G. & C. Carvill, 1828. 7 1828 Washington Irving, A History of the Life and Voyages of Christopher Columbus in Three Volumes, volume 3, New York: G. & C. Carvill, 1828. 7 1828 C.S. Stewart, Brazil and La Plata: Personal Record of a Cruise. New York: G.P. Putnam & Co., 1856. 7 1856 Biographical Review: This Volume Contains Biographical Sketches of the Volume 11: Leading Citizens of Otsego County, New York, Boston: Biographical Review Publishing, Co., 1893. 10 1893 Rand McNally Complete Atlas of the World, Chicago: Rand McNally & Company, 1922. 11 Subseries C: Family Bibles 13 12 Scope and Content

Subseries C contains the Bowers family’s bibles. These bibles do not contain much, if any, genealogical information.

 Bowers Family Bible A 12 undated Bowers Family Bible B 13 undated Series VII: Genealogy Research 8 1 1912, undated Scope and Content

This series consists of genealogical research. Most if not all of this research was initiated by Roy Campbell Smith. Notably in the first folder there are several documents from the Navy Department that prove Smith is descended from the Pomeroy family.

 Pomeroy Family 8 1 1912, undated Campbell Family 8 2 undated Bard, Bowers, Dandridge, Pendleton, and Smith Families 8 3 undated Genealogy Notes 8 4 undated Oversized Genealogy Materials OS 1 undated Series VIII: Ephemera 8 1813–1933, undated Scope and Content

This series consists of a variety of materials that show various aspects of the Bowers family’s everyday life. There are newspaper clippings, some that are related to the family and others that are not. There are calling cards, a greeting card, and even a recipe for sponge cake.

 Notes, Calling Cards, and Newspaper Clippings 8 5 1813–1933, undated
